Part A of title IV of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to allocate $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and subsequent years to carry out subpart 2. Subparts 2 and 3 are redesignated as 3 and 4, and sections are also redesignated accordingly. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to allocate funds for fiscal years to carry out subpart 2. Subparts and sections are redesignated accordingly. SEC. 4121. COMPREHENSIVE PREVENTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Secretary is authorized to provide grants to States for prevention programs meeting high scientific standards. States must submit a plan detailing grant selection criteria, funding only well-documented programs, and disseminating research-based materials. The State educational agency must ensure high quality, well-documented prevention programs are funded, disseminate research-based materials, evaluate program implementation, and measure results in preventing various behaviors and improving academic performance. The State educational agency must ensure that local programs meet requirements, funds supplement other sources, and meet criteria set by the Secretary. The Secretary reserves and allocates funds for each fiscal year to carry out the subpart, with reallocation to States that do not meet plan requirements. Funds allocated must be used to implement programs under this subpart. Each State educational agency receiving an award under this subpart must use funds to provide competitive grants to local educational agencies. Priority is given to agencies with demonstrated need, grant awards should support startup costs for a prevention plan, and equitable distribution is considered. The State educational agency must use funds to provide competitive grants to local educational agencies, prioritizing those with demonstrated need. Grants should support startup costs for a prevention plan and consider equitable distribution to different geographic regions within the State. The agency may use up to 5 percent of funds for administrative, evaluation, and technical assistance expenses. "Local awards under SEC. 4124 prioritize local educational agencies with demonstrated need, providing grants for prevention plan startup costs and ensuring equitable distribution within the State." To be eligible for a subgrant, a local educational agency must submit an application and a plan demonstrating how it will meet prevention program requirements based on reliable research to the State educational agency. The grant awarded should only be used for implementing prevention programs addressing various behaviors and improving student academic performance. The prevention programs funded by the grant must employ research-based strategies to address violence, substance abuse, and academic performance, while also focusing on the overall health and development of children and adolescents. The programs should include age-appropriate activities, interventions to improve cognitive and behavioral skills, active engagement of participants, and meaningful involvement of parents. The prevention programs funded by the grant must employ research-based strategies to address violence, substance abuse, and academic performance, while also focusing on the overall health and development of children and adolescents. The programs should include age-appropriate activities, interventions to improve cognitive, affective, and behavioral skills, active engagement of participants, meaningful involvement of parents, educators, health and mental health professionals, and the local community, high-quality staff professional development, measurable outcome goals, clear evaluation plan, and external technical support. The prevention programs funded by the grant must have measurable outcome goals, a clear evaluation plan, use external technical support, and identify how other resources will be used to support the effort.
